data.title: San Jose Jazz Summer Fest
data.text:
New Breed Brass Band fuses NOLA’s fertile brass band tradition with Caribbean, hip-hop, and modern R&B in the vein of Bruno Mars and Anderson .Paak. The explosive group makes music by and for the Crescent City’s next generation: joyful, vital and unstoppable.

Fusing watertight grooves with high energy shreds that will make you want to jump out of your seat, this 5-piece instrumental powerhouse has made a huge noise in the local scene, serving up soulful compositions, mind bending solos, & insanely funky jams.

Described as “sleek, new” and “hyper-fluent” by The New York Times, Pascal Le Boeuf is a Grammy Award-nominated composer, jazz pianist, and electronic artist whose works range from modern improvised music to hybridizing notation-based chamber music with production-based technology.

Benny Green received an invaluable early education from artists like Betty Carter, Art Blakey, Freddie Hubbard, and Ray Brown. Committed to playing honest jazz without needing recognition, Benny seeks to stand as a torchbearer for the continuum of straight-ahead jazz piano.

Performing timeless hits like “Hot Fun in the Summertime,” “Dance to the Music,” “I Want to Take You Higher” and more, The Family Stone carries on the funky legacy of Sly and the Family Stone and takes their relentlessly danceable groove into the future.

Las Cafeteras have taken the music scene by storm with their infectious live performances and have crossed many genres and borders along the way. Their eclectic sound and high-energy performances have taken them around the world playing shows at Bonnaroo, the Hollywood Bowl, WOMAD, Montreal Jazz Festival and beyond.

The SOJ Big Band was formed almost 20 years ago in the south San Francisco Bay Area to play big band arrangements of gospel, swing, latin, R&B and jazz tunes. The band has performed steadily since its inception in front of enthusiastic audiences and fans of ball room dancing.

In this special performance, local favorites Mason Razavi and Terrence Brewer pay homage to the great pianist Thelonious Monk, known for his influential style of dissonant voicings and off-beat rhythm. They are joined by first-call musicians Gary Brown and Sylvia Cuenca.

Grammy Award-nominated pianist, composer and arranger David Benoit has reigned as one the founding fathers of contemporary jazz for four decades. Benoit’s career as a contemporary jazz pianist has resulted in 40 solo recordings including Freedom at Midnight, Waiting for Spring and Shadows, which topped Billboard’s Contemporary Jazz Charts.

For more than four decades, Incognito—the British band co-founded and still led by singer, guitarist, composer and producer Jean-Paul “Bluey” Maunick—has explored the connections between jazz, funk and soul. Their vibrant, joyous live shows and innovative recordings have brought them a worldwide audience.

Black Joe Lewis & the Honeybears rock the PG&E Park Avenue Stage to kick off Summer Fest this year! A blues, funk, and soul outfit influenced by Howlin’ Wolf and James Brown, they have a raucous sound that is sure to get your blood pumping.

Telemakus is a 24 year old Indian-American self-taught pianist/producer/composer who gained acclaim after the release of his 2021 debut album, The New Heritage, a jazz funk fusion collection.

The Monterey Jazz Festival Regional All-Star Vocal ensemble features the top voice students from across Monterey County, who all come together to participate in an advanced choir.

Lucía Gutiérrez Rebolloso hails from Xalapa, the capital of the Mexican state of Veracruz. She is heir to a family of musicians steeped in son jarocho, a traditional regional style that blends Spanish, African and indigenous Mexican influences. Rebolloso was crowned the winner of the Sarah Vaughan International Jazz Vocal Competition in 2022.

The musical focus of the LGS Band is dance, jazz, Latin and vocals in all styles. The classics from Miller, Basie, Brown, and Goodman are among the featured songs as well as more modern works by arrangers such as Nestico, Goodwin, Carter, Hefti, Wolpe and more.

Winner of the 2023 Herbie Hancock Institute of Jazz International Piano Competition, Jahari Stampley has been hailed by the jazz legend himself as a “bold new voice.” His vigorous athleticism, juxtaposed with playing of poetic delicacy, has astounded audiences from coast to coast.

A Bay Area icon known for delighting audiences in jazz, blues, and cabaret clubs in the ‘70s and ‘80s, the Dynamic Miss Faye Carol has shared the stage with some of the most revered names in music, including Marvin Gaye, Ray Charles, Pharaoh Sanders.

The SJZ High School All Stars is a regional, audition-based music education program for students interested in the study and performance of jazz. The program includes a large ensemble and a combo.

The Monterey Jazz Festival Regional All-Star Band features the top music students from across Monterey County, who all come together to participate in middle and high school big bands.

Embodying both elegance and raw passion, Grace and The Grit are dedicated to keeping the spirit of blues alive. They bring together an exhilarating blend of soulful melodies and old school grittiness, performing with high energy and joy!

It takes a lot to stand out as a trumpeter in New Orleans, and Shamarr Allen has earned a spot on the top tier with his rollicking blend of jazz, hip-hop, funk and—even—country music. A 1000-watt performer, Allen carries and delivers the soul of New Orleans through his horn.

Hailed by The Boston Globe as a “premier exponent of chamamé”, composer and researcher Alejandro Brittes explores his chamamé heritage, an ancestral rhythm connecting us with the Earth and the Universe through music and dance, born of the encounter between the ritual musicality of the indigenous Guaraní and Baroque music.

Founded in Oakland in 2015, we are an assembly of world class jazz musicians, dedicated to sharing the joy of jazz with children (ages 9-17) through our after school classes and by performing concerts with our students, and sharing jazz through educational concerts with our community at large.

Footnotes Jazz is a San Francisco Bay Area ensemble that showcases contemporary and original big band jazz. Its founding members once played together in the Foothill College jazz program, before going independent under the leadership of Lori Stotko.

Playing on Grammy Award-nominated album Jazz Hands by Bob James, Andrey Chmut– Ukrainian saxophonist, composer, and producer– is at the forefront of contemporary jazz. His collaboration with Dave Burns is a silky smooth production informed by jazz history.

The JuJu Exchange is a musical partnership of three childhood friends from Chicago: Nico Segal and brothers Julian Reid and Nova Zaii (Everett Reid). Formed in 2016, the band creates exploratory and nuanced music that calls us all to wonder and trust.

Led by seven-time Grammy Award nominee John Santos, The John Santos Sextet is one of the premier Afro-Latin Jazz musical groups in the US. Santos has collaborated with masters like Tito Puente, Dizzy Gillespie, Max Roach, Eddie Palmieri, and McCoy Tyner, and was founder and director of the long-running Machete Ensemble from 1985 to 2006.

The SJZ High School All Stars is a regional, audition-based music education program for students interested in the study and performance of jazz. The program includes a large ensemble and a combo.

Agostini brothers Nea & Ale met JC Smith in 2010 when Nea & Ale were searching for international blues artists to play at their family’s venue in Santiago de Chile. It was then when they decided to form a band with their friends and outstanding musicians Américo Olivari & Álvaro Aguirre to accompany JC during his shows.

Top Shelf Big Band brings the swinging sounds of live jazz and ballroom dancing to life. Enjoy vintage jazz and standards made famous by groups like Duke Ellington, Count Basie, Glenn Miller and Les Brown with this 17-piece orchestra.

Five-time Grammy Award winner Angélique Kidjo hails from the West African nation of Benin. Her striking voice, stage presence and fluency in multiple cultures and languages have won respect from her peers and expanded her following across national borders. Time Magazine named her one of the 100 most influential people in the world in 2021.

Join a house band made up of alums from the San Jose Jazz High School All Stars U19s for a free, youth-focused community jazz jam during the Fest. If you’re 21 and under, bring your instrument and sign up for a slot. Or just take a break from the heat and listen as future jazz stars show you how it’s done.

Hailing from Havana, Cuba, Jorge Luis Pacheco is a virtuoso pianist, singer, composer, percussionist and arranger. His music has been described as a confluence of Afro-Cuban and American jazz and classical music, with a measure of contemporary pop and soul.

British-born jazz vocalist and bassist Janet Evra has released four critically-acclaimed records, and her most recent single, “Almost True,” features seven-time Grammy Award winner Randy Brecker and was selected for Spotify’s Vocal Jazz and Top Vocal Jazz 2023 playlists. At Summer Fest she’ll feature sparkling new material from her latest release, Meet Me in Paris.

She’s a DownBeat “Rising Star” trombonist. He’s a California Jazz Conservatory faculty member who plays alongside Brad Mehldau, Chris Potter and Lee Konitz. Together, Natalie Cressman and Ian Faquini have honed a singularly expansive creative communion encompassing their love of the Brazilian songbook, jazz, impressionism and sophisticated pop songcraft.

The Ames Jazz Band is a 17-piece big band comprised of musicians from the NASA Ames Research Center community and the surrounding area. We play classic Jazz, blues, and swing selections to enthusiastic audiences at clubs, dances, and festivals in the Bay Area.

Now in the seventh decade of his professional life, Herbie Hancock is a true icon of modern music. Still at the forefront of world culture, technology, business and music, he has been an integral part of every popular music movement since the 1960s.

Bloco do Sol is a community ensemble of youth and adult students based in San Jose at the School of Arts and Culture at the Mexican Heritage Plaza. Watch for this special pop-up performance in the Latin Tropical Stage area.

While deeply rooted in the jazz tradition, rising-star pianist and composer Sean Mason’s work transcends genre limitations, appealing to a diverse audience with its rich blend of cultural and musical influences. Mason’s artistry is a testament to his ability to navigate and integrate various musical landscapes.

Stephen Peterson and Stephen Vahle are the founders of the band Los Tocayos. The band plays music inspired by latin jazz greats Cal Tjader and Claire Fisher. The band features Peterson’s son Mike on bass and Karen Manrequez on vocals and her son Marcelo.

SE:UM has created a fusion of jazz and Korean traditional music, performed by virtuosos who are united through the pulsating beats of ancient folk tunes and shamanistic rhythms. Led by Joon Lee, recipient of the 2023 KBS Korean Traditional Music Award for his mastery of the 12-string gayageum, SE:UM is a powerhouse ensemble.

Saxophonist Kristen Strom has been a mainstay on the Bay Area music scene for nearly two decades, acclaimed for beautifully rendered melodies, exceptional tonality, and accomplished musicianship. Strom has played alongside many well-known artists, including Manhattan Transfer, Gladys Knight, Natalie Cole, Roberta Flack, Johnny Mathis, Jimmy Heath, Steve Turre, Taj Mahal, Ruthie Foster, Pamela Rose, and Jon Faddis.

It takes a lot to stand out as a trumpeter in New Orleans, and Shamarr Allen has earned a spot on the top tier with his rollicking blend of jazz, hip-hop, funk and—even—country music. A 1000-watt performer, Allen carries and delivers the soul of New Orleans through his horn.

Cory Henry is a pianist, organist, composer and producer who draws from myriad influences, including jazz, gospel, soul, hip-hop and funk. A former member of the worldwide jazz/funk phenomenon Snarky Puppy, he has released eight albums as a leader in the past decade.

Hailing from Havana, Cuba, Jorge Luis Pacheco is a virtuoso pianist, singer, composer, percussionist and arranger. His music has been described as a confluence of Afro-Cuban and American jazz and classical music, with a measure of contemporary pop and soul.

Join Korean folk-jazz fusion group SE:UM and Summer Fest’s world music curator, Bettos Arcos, for a discussion about SE:UM’s journey as a band from their self-titled 2015 debut album through their modern retelling of a Korean folktale about the bamboo pipe that saved the world, inspired by the turbulence of the COVID-19 epidemic.

Now into their third decade, Spanish Harlem Orchestra, the three-time Grammy Award winning salsa and Latin jazz band, sets the gold standard for excellence in authentic, danceable, New York-style, hardcore salsa.With an unwavering respect for the music’s storied history, the ensemble’s 13 world-class musicians and vocalists come together to create an unparalleled musical experience.

Nico Segal is a trumpeter and producer from Chicago who has collaborated with a long list of diverse talents, most notably hip-hop superstar Chance the Rapper. In 2013, Segal (under a previous stage name, Donnie Trumpet) and Chance teamed up in the highly regarded band Social Experiment.

Fusing watertight grooves with high energy shreds that will make you want to jump out of your seat, this 5-piece instrumental powerhouse has made a huge noise in the local scene, serving up soulful compositions, mind bending solos, & insanely funky jams.

Add some soul to your Summer Fest experience by dropping in on Sunday to Urban Sanctuary, home of Neil MacPherson’s Hammond B3 organ. The Hammond organ has played a unique role in integrating church and club to bring a vibrant, soulful sound to both.

Sunday morning, join our friends at First Unitarian Church of San José for a celebration with a jazz accent. This year’s theme, “Off the Page: Imagination Unbound,” is inspired by musical stories that transport us through lyrics and sound to new spaces, places, and feelings.

Enjoy a Sunday morning filled with delicious food and uplifting music, 11am–1pm, on the final day of the festival. This year’s brunch will feature vocalist Joyce Randolph accompanied on keys by Janice Maxie Reid.

Over his 43 year career, trombonist and composer Michael Davis, leader of Hip-Bone Big Band, has gone on five world tours with the Rolling Stones, toured and recorded extensively with Frank Sinatra, released 11 CDs as a solo artist, and appeared on over 500 CDs, television themes and motion picture soundtracks.

Ayo Brame is an up and coming tenor saxophone jazz musician out of Oakland. A student of the Oakland School for the Arts, he is trained by jazz great Richard Howell by way of Oaktown Jazz Workshops. He considers himself a purist when it comes to jazz as he channels late greats such as John Coltrane and Wayne Shorter.

Brian Ho has dedicated countless hours to mastering the rich history of the Hammond Organ on and off the bandstand, while simultaneously adding his voice and influences into the music. Joined by drummer Byron “Wookie” Landham and other alumni of Joey Defrancesco’s trio, Grammy Award Nominated guitarist Dan Wilson, this performance will premiere songs from Ho’s new album, Bridges.

Grammy-nominated accordionist Andre Thierry has become an international icon of Accordion Soul. Rooted in his French-Creole heritage, Thierry’s music celebrates his background while integrating funk and R&B elements. His albums feature the accordion as an upbeat, rhythmic instrument that sounds equally at home in a New Orleans church gathering or on the dance floor.

Six-time Grammy Award Winner and twelve-time Grammy Award Nominee Daniel Ho is regarded as one of the most prolific and successful musicals Hawaii has ever produced (Ukulele Magazine). He is a ukulele virtuoso, singer-songwriter, composer, producer, and so much more! Ho is a world-renowned musician– collaborating across genres with Mongolian nomads, Taiwanese aboriginals, and contemporary jazz/rock artists like Tak Matsumoto.

Full Spectrum Big Band has delighted audiences with traditional and modern big band sounds since 1996. The band members enjoy keeping jazz alive in the community while actively supporting the role of jazz education in schools.

An award-winning jazz composer, guitarist and vocalist, Dr. Pascal Bokar Thiam presents a global musical banquet from his native France to his Senegalese and Malian roots. Anchored in bebop, he has performed with Dizzy Gillespie, Donald Byrd, Donald Bailey and Donald Brown.

Ms. Lisa Fischer built her stellar reputation as a background singer with such giants as the Rolling Stones, Sting, Tina Turner and Luther Vandross. Now, accompanied by the band Grand Baton, Ms. Fischer—featured in the Oscar-winning 2013 documentary Twenty Feet from Stardom—is stepping out front.

Known as one of the top jazz fusion bassists and composers in Northern California, Ken Okada has performed in clubs and festivals all over the state. At Summer Fest, he performs material including his latest project, Young and Brave, with 14-year-old Japanese rock drummer YOYOKA, who has racked up over 30 million views on YouTube.

Take a break at our Official Hotel Partner, the San Jose Marriott, meet the author of Bird of Four Hundred Voices and get your copy signed! Written by Eugene Rodriguez, the book chronicles the extraordinary journey of Los Cenzontles from a barrio youth group into an internationally acclaimed beacon of cultural preservation and education in San Pablo, California.

The East Bay Jazz High School All-Stars is an after-school program dedicated to creating high-caliber musical performance and education for high school jazz musicians in the East Bay Area.

Jane Monheit is a vocalist with a deep passion for the Great American Songbook. She is a successful bandleader, and has made music with some of the greatest figures in jazz. After more than 20 years, 12 albums and countless guest appearances, she continues to tour the world playing major halls, clubs and festivals.

A select group of the San Jose Jazz High School All Stars Big Band, the SJZ U19s feature our finest young musicians in a small combo setting.

Vibraphonist, composer and arranger NIKARA’s debut album, Black Wall Street, is a convergence of hip-hop, jazz, neo-soul, Afro-Latin and more. Granddaughter of Kenny Barron, she has played at the Kennedy Center, the SFJazz Center and, most recently, at NYC’s 20th Anniversary Winter Jazz Fest.

Since its founding in 2007, Delfeayo Marsalis and the Uptown Jazz Orchestra have grown into one of the premier large ensembles in the world, releasing three critically acclaimed albums and touring internationally. They leap between swing, Latin, and New Orleans with ease and style, educating youth and elevating New Orleans culture with their music.

Award-winning vocalist, instrumentalist and songwriter Curtis Salgado, the man NPR calls “an icon” with “a huge voice,” is revered worldwide for his ability to wring every ounce of soul out of every song he performs. Salgado is famed not only for his powerhouse live shows and eleven previous albums, but also for his passionate and insightful original songs.

Pianist Mike LeDonne, practically raised in his family’s music store, started playing piano at five. He is now an internationally renowned pianist and organist who has played with some of the world’s foremost jazz masters: from Benny Goodman to Milt Jackson and Sonny Rollins. He has won praise not only from critics but from master musicians: Oscar Peterson called him “incredible” and “one of the most talented pianists of this particular era.”

Bloco do Sol is a community ensemble of youth and adult students based in San Jose at the School of Arts and Culture at the Mexican Heritage Plaza. Watch for this special pop-up performance in the Latin Tropical Stage area.

Uruguayan born singer, percussionist, composer and Band Leader, Edgardo Cambón, “El Sonero Del Uruguay” and his Orchestra “Candela,” return to Summer Fest to present his latest exciting and very danceable show, “Original y Bailable.”

Hailed by The Boston Globe as a “premier exponent of chamamé”, composer and researcher Alejandro Brittes explores his chamamé heritage, an ancestral rhythm connecting us with the Earth and the Universe through music and dance, born of the encounter between the ritual musicality of the indigenous Guaraní and Baroque music.

A highly instinctive blues artist who dropped out of school at 15 years old to play guitar professionally, Eddie 9V replicates the sound of the late 60s and evokes blues legends like Muddy Waters, Howlin’ Wolf, and Freddie King on stage.

Founded by vocalist Frankie Beverly in Philadelphia in 1970, R&B legend Maze had nine gold albums between 1977 and 1993 with monster hits like “Happy Feelin’s” and “Before I Let Go.” Fresh off the band’s Farewell Tour, Beverly makes one last guest appearance, as the band introduces Maze’s new lead singer, Tony Lindsay.

An SJZ Jazz Aid Fund artist who sold out his New Works Fest show this March, Ayo Brame has reached a mastery of the jazz idiom at the age of 16 that musicians twice his age can only dream of. A gifted and technical improviser, Ayo’s shy off-stage presence belies ferocious ambition.

The Montreal-based JUNO award-winning singer-songwriter Dominique Fils-Aimé puts the history of African-American musical culture into the heart of her work. Her music reflects on the social realities that influenced the genres of blues, jazz and soul.

Jimmy Bosch, featured on eleven Grammy Award Winning CD productions, is a trombonist, singer, dancer, composer, and producer with more than one-hundred fifty Salsa and Latin Jazz recordings. Performing in over one hundred countries across the world– Bosch is considered one of the most important exponents of the New York Style Afro Caribbean music known as “Salsa Dura”.

Vibraphonist, composer and arranger NIKARA’s debut album, Black Wall Street, is a convergence of hip-hop, jazz, neo-soul, Afro-Latin and more. Granddaughter of Kenny Barron, she has played at the Kennedy Center, the SFJazz Center and, most recently, at NYC’s 20th Anniversary Winter Jazz Fest.
